Question:
Why did the TathÄgata not extensively expound the meaning that should be explained?
Answer:

The TathÄgata observes ten kinds of benefits and briefly explains the dharmas, namely, easy to establish, easy to proclaim, easy to uphold, out of respect for the Dharma, quickly attaining the perfection of the requisites for enlightenment, quickly penetrating the true nature of dharmas, attaining pure faith in the Buddhas, attaining pure faith in the Dharma and Saá¹ƒgha, touching and realizing the supreme present happiness of abiding in the Dharma, discussing and resolving to delight the minds of the wise, and attaining the number of the wise and sagacious.
What is called easy to establish?
The expounders of the Dharma, with innumerable approaches, establish and reveal the meaning to be explained. Now, with few words, it is easy to establish.
What is called easy to proclaim?
It is because one can extensively reveal the great meaning with few words.
As it is said, one can cause the mind to abide in equanimity, and so on, and explain it extensively in this way.
As for easy to uphold, it is because it causes those who can listen to easily accept and uphold it, out of respect for the Dharma.

The accumulations for enlightenment are quickly perfected means that by realizing the profound wisdom that understands the Buddha's teachings, one deeply cherishes those teachings. Because of this cherishing, the accumulations such as faith are quickly perfected.

One is quickly able to penetrate the true nature of dharmas means that by the power of skillful means that respect the Dharma, one's wisdom becomes even more sharp and able, gradually penetrating the true nature of dharmas.
One attains the purity of faith in the Three Jewels means that by understanding the excellent establishment of the holy teachings, pure faith arises in the expounder and so forth.

It is called extensive, and also called extensive destruction, and also called incomparable.

Question:

The two extremes are the extreme of indulgence in sensual pleasures and the extreme of self-mortification.
To counteract indulgence, it prohibits the accumulation and hoarding of possessions, etc., and allows the proper use of hundreds of thousands of Dharma robes, etc.

In order to counteract the secondary affliction of clinging to one's own views, the Abhidharma Piá¹­aka is established, because it extensively explains the characteristics of the various dharmas as they really are.

Relying on pure morality, one gives rise to no regrets and so forth, gradually learning and practicing to attain concentration.

Question:
To what is the dharma included in these three baskets an object?
Answer:
It is the object of the mind and mental factors produced by hearing, thinking, and cultivation.
The object is the meaning of the object.
Furthermore, based on this object-characteristic, the meaning of having an object, etc. is established for mind and mental factors.
As a sutra says:
All minds and mental factors have an object, have a mode of activity, have a support, and are associated.
What is the object of these dharmas?
It refers to sutras, etc.
This shows that the teachings such as sutras, etc. included in the collections of names, phrases, and syllables are the objects.
What is the mode of activity?
It refers to the meaning associated with the aggregates, etc.
This shows that the teachings that arise based on the meaning of the aggregates, etc. are the mode of activity of those minds and mental factors.
What is the support?
It refers to the expression of others, memory, and habitual tendencies.
This shows that when correctly expounding the Dharma, one uses the expression of others as the support, as it is said to arise from the sounds of others' speech.
Subsequently, memory becomes the support, as one recollects and cultivates what has been heard.
After that, the perfuming of the mind is the support. Due to the power of the strong perfuming of later cultivation, even if memory is absent, it appears similar to that.
What is association?
It means mutually assisting each other, equally understanding the object.
Because the mind and mental factors mutually assist each other, they equally understand the object with the characteristics of aggregates, etc. in the objects such as sÅ«tras.
How is the distinction of objects in the Dharma?
In brief, there are four kinds: objects of universal pervasion, objects of counteractive practice, objects of skillful means, and objects of purifying afflictions.

Objects of universal pervasion are also of four kinds: objects of images with discrimination, objects of images without discrimination, objects of the limit of phenomena, and objects of accomplishment.
Objects of images with discrimination refer to the objects of Å›amatha and vipaÅ›yanÄ that are cultivated by the intention of superior understanding.
The attention of resolve is exclusively mundane attention.
The objective supports of non-discriminating images refer to the objective supports of calming and insight that are cultivated by the attention of reality.
The attention of reality is exclusively supramundane, as well as the attention attained subsequently to that.
The objective supports of the limits of phenomena refer to the totality of all phenomena and the suchness of all phenomena.
The totality of all phenomena refers to the aggregates, sense bases, and sense fields.
In order to reveal that the substance and events of all knowable phenomena are only of this extent and limit, therefore the three, aggregates, sense bases, and sense fields, are established.
The suchness of all phenomena refers to the sixteen aspects of the four noble truths and their true suchness.

All conditioned things are impermanent, all conditioned things are suffering, all dharmas are without self, nirvana is quiescent, empty, wishless, and signless. By means of such meanings and distinctions, one understands the objects of knowledge, therefore it is called the suchness of all phenomena.

Or, by means of the gate of truths, one understands the known realm, namely, the previously mentioned aggregates, realms, and sense fields, which one should understand as suffering, up to the path, as appropriate.

Or, by means of the gate of practices, one understands the known realm, namely, each of the truths by means of the four practices, and all dharmas without distinction are all the practice of suchness.
Or, by means of the gate of the Udana of all dharmas, one understands the known realm, namely, all conditioned things are impermanent, up to nirvana is quiescent.
Or, by means of the gate of liberation, one understands the known realm, namely, emptiness, wishlessness, and signlessness, and so forth.
The object of support for accomplishing what is to be done refers to the transformation of the basis.
For one who has attained the transformation of the basis, the object of support that is free from error becomes manifest.
Thus, the transformation of the basis is inconceivable.
The sixteen practices and three gates of liberation that were previously said to exist in the nature of things as they are, these two kinds mutually include each other.

Answer:
The second is the practice of emptiness and the practice of non-self.
Question:
How many practices are included in the wishless?
Answer:

Six, namely the practice of impermanence, the practice of suffering, the practice of causes, the practice of accumulation, the practice of birth, and the practice of conditions, because they do not wish for anything in the three realms.
Question:
How many practices are included in the signless?
Answer:
Eight, namely the eight practices of cessation and the path, because they are unable to practice signs.

The objects of practice for counteracting are, in brief, of five kinds, namely for those with much greed, the object of impurity, for those with much anger, the object of cultivating kindness, for those with much delusion, the object of dependent origination with various conditions, for those with pride, the object of the distinctions of realms, and for those with discursive thoughts, the object of mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation.
Why do those with much greed, etc. cultivate the objects of practice for counteracting by means of impurity, etc.?
Because this can eliminate excessive greed, etc.
Skillful objects are of five kinds: skill in the aggregates, skill in the elements, skill in the sense bases, skill in dependent origination, and skill in what is possible and impossible.
How should one contemplate skill in what is possible and impossible?
One should contemplate it as skill in dependent origination.
Question:
What is the difference between skill in dependent origination and skill in what is possible and impossible?
Answer:
If it is the case that dharmas moisten other dharmas, causing them to be born without a cause or from an unequal cause, this is skill in dependent origination.

That is to say, the dharmas such as ignorance moisten the dharmas such as karmic formations. Those dharmas are not born without a cause, nor are they born from an unequal cause such as the Lord of Creation. Such wisdom is called skill in dependent origination.
Because cause and effect correspond to each other and are accepted and produced, this is skill in what is possible and impossible.
Although there are only dharmas as causes, yet by accepting causes that correspond to each other, one is able to produce effects that correspond to each other.
For example, good conduct leads to desirable results, while evil conduct leads to undesirable results.
This kind of insight is called skill in the possible and impossible.
The objects of eliminating afflictions are the coarseness of the lower realms and the calmness of the higher realms, suchness, and the four noble truths.
The coarseness of the lower realms and the calmness of the higher realms are explained based on the worldly path, because by this one subdues the bonds.
Suchness and the four noble truths are explained based on the supramundane path.
Because by this one completely destroys the latent tendencies.
Next, having analyzed the scriptures and so forth, one should explain the principles of the teachings, because by relying on these principles one can understand those teachings.
Question:
If one wishes to correctly and carefully investigate the teachings, by how many kinds of principles can one correctly investigate them?
Answer:
It is due to four kinds of principles: the principle of dependence, the principle of performance of function, the principle of proof, and the principle of nature.

The principle of dependence means that when dharmas arise, they must depend on various conditions. For example, when a sprout arises, it must depend on conditions such as seeds, time, water, fields, etc. When consciousness arises, it must depend on conditions such as faculties, objects, attention, etc. This is the case.

The principle of performance of function means that dharmas with different characteristics each have their own function. For example, the function of the eye faculty, etc. is to be the support for eye consciousness, etc. The function of form, etc. as objects is to be the objects of eye consciousness, etc. The eye consciousness, etc. cognize form, etc.;
It is like this for gold and silver craftsmen skillfully creating gold and silver objects, and so on.
The principle of proof means speaking words that are not contradictory to the various means of valid cognition in order to prove what should be proven.
What should be proven means the meaning that should be proven, which is included in the distinctions of self-nature.
The words not contradicted by any means of valid cognition mean that the statements of the thesis, etc. are not contradicted by direct perception, etc.

The principle of natural law means that in the dharmas that abide in their own characteristics and general characteristics from beginningless time, there are dharmas that are accomplished by the nature of dharmas.
For example, fire can burn and water can rot. Such dharmas are accomplished by the nature of dharmas.
As it is said in the sutra:
Although the eyes are perfectly clear, they are empty, without permanence, up to without self.
Why is it so?
It is because their nature is such.
Furthermore, having correctly contemplated the four principles in the dharmas, how does one give rise to investigation?
It means giving rise to four kinds of investigation:
1. Investigation of names, 2. Investigation of phenomena, 3. Investigation of the positing of self-natures, 4. Investigation of the positing of distinctions.
Investigation of names means seeking out the self-characteristics of the collections of names, phrases, and syllables, all of which are not truly established.
Because name-group, etc., are nominally existent, their own characteristics are all unreal.
The investigation of objects means to investigate the characteristics of the aggregates, realms, and sense bases of all dharmas and find them to be unreal.
Because the objects such as the aggregates, etc., are like the name-group, etc., and the characteristics they proclaim are all unreal. Therefore, one observes that their characteristics are unreal.
Investigation means the meaning of observation.

The investigation of the nominal designation of substance means to investigate the substance of all dharmas within the correspondence between the expounder and the expounded and find it to be only the nature of the cause of verbal expression.
Correspondence between the expounder and the expounded means that these two are the nature of the cause of mutual understanding.
Why is this so?
Those skilled in language only hear the expounder and, by the door of recollection, can give rise to understanding of the expounded.
Or, they only attain the expounded and, by the door of recollection, can give rise to understanding of the expounder.

In this kind of mutually established correspondence, the specific characteristics of the eyes and so forth are only nominally established, because these terms arise only as causes for verbal expressions in regard to the flesh and so forth.
If one observes in this way, this is called the investigation of the nominal establishment of self-nature.

The investigation of the nominal establishment of distinctions refers to seeking distinctions only as causes for nominal expressions in regard to the correspondence between the expressed and the means of expression.
Why is this so?

Because in seeking distinctions in the correspondence between the expressed and the means of expression, such as permanence and impermanence, superiority and inferiority, form and non-form, visibility and invisibility, etc., they are only causes for nominal expressions that are nominally established.
Observing in this way is called the investigation of the nominal establishment of distinctions.
Furthermore, having cultivated the investigation of dharmas with right effort, one will certainly attain the knowledge of reality in regard to all dharmas.
How does one give rise to the knowledge of reality?
It refers to giving rise to the four knowledges of reality:

The first is the knowledge of reality induced by the investigation of names, the second is the knowledge of reality induced by the investigation of things, the third is the knowledge of reality induced by the investigation of the positing of self-nature, and the fourth is the knowledge of reality induced by the investigation of the positing of distinctions.
The knowledge of reality induced by the investigation of names means the knowledge that realizes names are unobtainable.
The knowledge of reality induced by the investigation of things means the knowledge that realizes the characteristics of things are also unobtainable.
The knowledge of reality induced by the investigation of the positing of self-nature means the knowledge that realizes the real self-nature is unobtainable.
The knowledge of reality induced by the investigation of the positing of distinctions means the knowledge that realizes the real distinctions are unobtainable.
These four knowledges of reality, as previously investigated, realize that names, etc. are all unobtainable.
Next, how should one understand the yoga stage of cultivating samÄdhi based on the Dharma?
This stage is generally of five kinds: support, reliance, mirror, illumination, and basis.

Support means that having already accumulated the requisites for enlightenment, in the stages of heat and so forth, one relies on the various truths and has much hearing. As one establishes the objects of calm abiding and insight according to what one has heard much, it is called support.

Moreover, one who has already accumulated the requisites for enlightenment, in order to seek the realization of the truths, listens to and accepts the teachings such as the sutras, and is therefore called one who has heard much.

Reliance means that taking this as the object, one properly directs the mind. Due to this proper attention, one relies on what one has heard and correctly contemplates, holding the mental image of the meaning of what one has heard in the mind.

Mirror means that taking this as the object, there is a samÄdhi with characteristics. This samÄdhi takes what one has heard as its object, and is accompanied by the characteristics of concentration, and is therefore called with characteristics. Because this samÄdhi still bears the image of the same class as the known object,
and because this samÄdhi can carefully examine the substance of the known object, it is likened to a mirror.
Clear refers to the wisdom that does not attain the grasper and the grasped. This is because the wisdom that is included in the path of seeing turns to realize the truth.
How do bodhisattvas practice according to the stages of yoga to realize the non-attainment of objects?

It is said that bodhisattvas who have already well accumulated the two kinds of provisions of merit and wisdom, who have already passed the first incalculably long eon, who have already heard the sÅ«tras and other teachings that accord with the realization of suchness, who have given rise to samÄdhi through proper mental activity, who rely on the mind in samÄdhi to contemplate the images of objects known in samÄdhi, who contemplate these images as no different from the mind in samÄdhi, who abandon thoughts of external objects based on these images, and who only observe their own mental images in samÄdhi.
At that time, because the bodhisattvas know that all phenomena are only their own minds, they internally abide in their minds and know that all kinds of grasped objects do not exist at all.
Because the grasped does not exist, all the grasper is also not real, and therefore they subsequently know that the grasper does not exist.
Next, internally abandoning the two kinds of natures that are attained, one realizes the non-attainment.
Based on this principle, the Buddha BhagavÄn has wonderfully and well proclaimed:
The bodhisattva, in meditative concentration, observes that images are only mind. When the conceptualization of meaning is eliminated, he carefully observes only his own conceptualization.
Knowing that the mind abides within, knowing that the object taken is non-existent, next the subject is also non-existent, and finally he touches the non-attainment.
Basis refers to the transformation of the basis, abandoning all coarseness and attaining the pure transformation of the basis.

It should be known that here the causal and resultant stages are explained by the yoga stages. The four kinds such as upholding explain the cause of this stage, and the final one kind explains the result of this stage.

What is skill in the Dharma?

What is skill in meaning?
It is because one is well-versed in the characteristics of Abhidharma and Vinaya that one is skilled in meaning and is able to receive much.
If one is well-versed in the characteristics of Abhidharma and so forth, then one will be able to collect many texts within the topics explained such as the aggregates, realms, bases, and so forth.
What is skill in the text?
It is because one is well-versed in the interpretation of words and phrases.
What is skill in language?
It means being able to skillfully understand the conventional expressions such as I and mine, not deeply attached to them, and speaking in accordance with them.
If one is skillful in both words and phrases, one will be able to skillfully receive what is spoken.
Because one skillfully understands the interpretation of words and phrases, one skillfully understands the conventional expressions such as I and mine.
Because one does not deeply cling to them and speaks in accordance with them, one is able to receive the meaning of the words without error.
What is skillful in the profound meaning of the past and future?
It means being able to skillfully understand the reception in the past and the liberation in the future.

If one is skillful in the profound meaning of the past and future, one will be able to receive and not lose it, because one relies on the Dharma received in the past and is able to realize liberation in the future.
By skillfully understanding the profound meaning of the TathÄgata, one will be able to realize the solidity of the holy teachings.
What is it to abide in the Dharma among all dharmas?
If one cannot cultivate the wisdom of practice, but only diligently applies expedient means to cultivate hearing and contemplation, one cannot be said to abide in the Dharma.
If one cannot cultivate hearing and contemplation, but only diligently applies expedient means to cultivate the wisdom of practice, one also cannot be said to abide in the Dharma.
If one obtains both kinds of expedient means and abides in them, then one can be said to abide in the Dharma.
As the sutra says:

In this sutra, the World-Honored One shows that if one is able to fully rely on hearing, contemplation, and practice, then one is called one who abides in the Dharma;
It is not that by following and abiding in one kind of expedient means of cultivation one can be called one who abides in the Dharma.
If one only upholds and recites the Dharma, expounds it for others, and so forth, this is called the wisdom born from hearing and contemplation.

It is said that if one focuses too much on the text, recites and explains it, and thinks about it too much, only cultivating the wisdom of hearing and thinking, not cultivating the wisdom of practice, and abandoning yoga and so forth, one cannot be established as abiding in the Dharma.
If one is not content with the means of cultivating samÄdhi, this is called the wisdom born of cultivation.
It is said that if one does not attain the wisdom of hearing and thinking but only cultivates the wisdom of practice, one still cannot be established as abiding in the Dharma.
Therefore, the World-Honored One, because of the bhiká¹£us who abide in the Dharma, spoke thus:
If a bhiká¹£u is consummate in the Dharma, namely the sÅ«tras and verses, and so forth in detail.
Later, he also said, Do not abandon yoga, and so forth. One should understand this in accordance with the principle.
If one is endowed with the wisdom of hearing, thinking, and cultivation, and abides in the two kinds of abodes, this is called abiding in the Dharma and not abandoning yoga.
And so forth refers to not being content with the means of cultivating samÄdhi, which shows the wisdom born of cultivation.
The expedient means of samÄdhi refer to uninterrupted and earnest expedient means, as well as non-inverted expedient means.
This then reveals two kinds of expedient means:
First, it includes what is subsumed by uninterrupted and earnest expedient means, as stated in not abandoning yoga.
Second, it includes what is subsumed by non-inverted expedient means, as stated in not abandoning attention.
As for being insatiable, it refers to not giving rise to a sense of satisfaction in cultivating the expedient means of higher Å›amatha, as stated in not abandoning internal mental Å›amatha.
This then reveals that because one does not give rise to a sense of satisfaction, and because one cultivates the expedient means of higher Å›amatha, it is called not abandoning.
Next, for what reasons is the vaipulya portion among the twelve divisions of the Buddhist canon called the piá¹­aka of the perfections of the bodhisattvas?

Because in this section, all the perfections are extensively explained in terms of their number, characteristics, sequence, etymological explanations, cultivation, distinctions, inclusion, antidotes, merits, and mutual discernment.
Question:
Where are they explained?
Answer:
As the sutra says, the Great Vehicle is the treasury of the perfections for bodhisattvas.
How are the number, characteristics, sequence, and so forth of the perfections explained, up to their mutual discernment?
The number is of two kinds:
one is the calculated number, and the other is the definite number.
The calculated number refers to the six perfections.
The definite number means that the number of perfections is only six, neither more nor less.
Why is this?
In brief, there are two kinds of paths for all bodhisattvas:
one is the path of superior birth, and the other is the path of decisive victory.
They are included in the first three and the last three, respectively.
Why is this?
There are three kinds of superior births:
great wealth, great body, and great retinue.
The perfection of giving leads to the fruition of great wealth.
The perfection of morality leads to the fruition of a great body, because by upholding pure precepts one is born in good destinies and obtains a noble body.
The perfection of patience leads to the fruition of a great retinue, because those who can practice patience are all followed by sentient beings.
There are three kinds of decisive victory:
skillful means for subduing afflictions and cultivating wholesome qualities, skillful means for maturing sentient beings, and skillful means for maturing the Buddha's teachings.
If any one of these three is lacking, the bodhisattva's decisive victory will certainly not be accomplished.
Skillful means for maturing sentient beings refers to the perfection of meditation, because based on this one gives rise to spiritual powers and matures sentient beings.
Moreover, the perfections are the skillful means for the nirvÄá¹‡a with no fixed abode, and therefore their number is only six.
Why is this so?
Because all bodhisattvas, in order to turn away from abiding in nirvÄá¹‡a, gather the most excellent rebirth in saá¹ƒsÄra;
in order to turn away from abiding in saá¹ƒsÄra, they are not defiled by saá¹ƒsÄra.

Therefore, the first three are the skillful means for attaining the most excellent rebirth, and the last three are the skillful means for being undefiled, as one should understand according to the circumstances.

As for the skillful means for being undefiled, through vigor one cultivates the antidotes, through meditative absorption one subdues the afflictions, and through wisdom one utterly destroys all the latent tendencies of the afflictions.
Moreover, in order to benefit all sentient beings and to counteract all afflictions, the perfections are only of six kinds.
Why is this so?
Because bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, through giving, attract wealth and skillfully benefit all sentient beings.

Because of observing the precepts, one does not give rise to harm, oppression, or disturbance, and skillfully benefits all sentient beings, as in the sequence, because one does not destroy others' wealth and body and mind.
Because of patience, one is able to endure harm, oppression, and disturbance, and skillfully benefits all sentient beings, because one is able to endure others' harm to one's wealth, etc.
By these three, one is able to skillfully benefit all sentient beings.
Because of vigor, although one has not yet permanently subdued all afflictions, one relies on wholesome states to cultivate their antidotes.
Because of meditative concentration, one permanently subdues the afflictions.
Because of wisdom, one permanently destroys the latent tendencies.
By these three, one is able to skillfully counteract all afflictions.
The characteristics refer to the characteristics of the perfections of bodhisattvas.
What are the characteristics of the perfection of generosity?

That is to say, when bodhisattvas abide in the nature of bodhisattvas, take enlightenment mind as their basis, lead their minds with compassion, and give up all bodily, verbal, and mental actions at all times.
In this way, by means of their spiritual lineage, vows, intentions, activities, and essence, the characteristics of the perfection of giving are revealed.
As for spiritual lineage, it refers to the nature of bodhisattvas.
As for vows, it refers to the mind of enlightenment.
As for intentions, it refers to leading the mind with compassion.
As for activities, it refers to giving up all possessions.
As for essence, it refers to bodily, verbal, and mental actions.
What are the characteristics of the perfection of morality?

That is to say, when bodhisattvas abide in the nature of bodhisattvas, take enlightenment mind as their basis, lead their minds with compassion, and receive and uphold all bodhisattva precepts, all bodily, verbal, and mental actions at that time.
What are the characteristics of the perfection of patience?

That is, when bodhisattvas abide in the nature of bodhisattvas, take enlightenment mind as their basis, lead their minds with compassion, and endure and accept the sufferings of all enemies, it is the activities of body, speech, and mind.
What are the characteristics of the perfection of vigor?

That is, when bodhisattvas abide in the nature of bodhisattvas, take enlightenment mind as their basis, lead their minds with compassion, and give rise to all supreme wholesome dharmas, it is the activities of body, speech, and mind.
What are the characteristics of the perfection of meditation?

That is, when bodhisattvas abide in the nature of bodhisattvas, take enlightenment mind as their basis, lead their minds with compassion, and give rise to the sovereign functions of all kinds of activities of body, speech, and mind, their minds always abide in tranquility.
What are the characteristics of the perfection of wisdom?

That is to say, when the bodhisattvas abide in the bodhisattva nature, take enlightenment thought as their basis, lead their minds with compassion, and give rise to all kinds of physical, verbal, and mental actions and their mastery, it is the discernment of all dharmas.

Furthermore, if the giving that is practiced is based on the nature of omniscience, can induce the nature of omniscience, embraces the nature of omniscience, and can accomplish all the affairs of omniscience, this is called the characteristic of the perfection of giving.
These four sentences manifest the characteristics of the perfections in order, by means of their arousal, habitual tendencies, essence, and natural outflow.
Arousal refers to all the practices of giving that are based on the nature of omniscience and all return to the nature of omniscience.
Habitual tendencies refer to what can induce the nature of omniscience.
It is the perfuming and cultivation of the giving that is practiced, which in the future can induce the nature of omniscience.
As for the essence, it refers to the possession of the nature of omniscience.
This is the ultimate perfection of the practice of giving, because at that time one is able to accomplish the Dharma body of a Buddha.
As for the outflow, it refers to being able to perform all the activities of omniscience.
From that time onward, through the door of the outflow of the enjoyment body and transformation body, etc., one gives rise to all the activities of omniscience.
Just as with the characteristics of the perfection of giving, the characteristics of the perfections of morality up to wisdom should all be explained in the same way.
As for the sequence, it refers to the fact that the preceding perfections serve as the basis for the succeeding ones.
Why is this so?

Because bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, through the practice of the perfection of giving and the relinquishment of internal and external things, do not care about their bodies and lives, abandon great treasures, and uphold the precepts.
Because of protecting the precepts, even if others scold them, they never respond in kind.

Because of this, one is able to endure. Because one is able to endure the suffering of cold and heat, even if one encounters these conditions, one does not cease one's practice and gives rise to diligent effort.
Through diligent effort and skillful means, one realizes the ultimate fruit and perfects meditative absorption.
Having perfected meditative absorption, because the mind of pure concentration knows reality as it is, one realizes the ultimate great wisdom that transcends the world.
Furthermore, the previous perfections are upheld by the subsequent ones.
That is to say, morality upholds giving, up to wisdom upholding meditative absorption.
Morality perfects giving.
Why is this?
Because by practicing giving one benefits sentient beings, and by possessing morality one does not harm them.
Therefore, the bodhisattva, by being free from harming those who receive his giving, is well able to give them pure enjoyments. Thus, by the power of pure morality, giving is perfected.
In the same way, by the power of patience, morality is perfected.
Why is this?
Because by being able to endure the harm done by others, one never violates the precepts one has undertaken.
Because of vigor, patience becomes pure.
Why is this?
Because by the power of courage, one is able to endure the suffering of sentient beings' opposition and so forth for a long time in saá¹ƒsÄra without considering it difficult.
Because of meditative absorption, vigor becomes pure.
Why is this?
Because by being accompanied by joy and pleasure, one is able to diligently cultivate all wholesome dharmas without rest.
Because of wisdom, meditative absorption becomes pure.
Why is this?
If one repeatedly contemplates dharmas through innumerable approaches, one is able to realize inner tranquility and increase samÄdhi.
Moreover, a verse from the GÄthÄ says:
There is no meditative absorption that does not rely on wisdom.
Furthermore, the sequence of the perfections is in terms of coarse and fine.
Why is this?
Among the practices, giving is the coarsest, so it is established first.
In the practice of patience and so forth, morality is again the coarsest, and therefore it is established next.
Up to the practice of wisdom, meditative absorption is the coarsest, and wisdom is the most subtle among all practices, and therefore it is established last.

As for the explanation of the terms, the reason why the giving practiced by bodhisattvas is called the perfection of giving is that it is called the perfection of giving because of great giving, freedom from faults, and freedom from defilements.
Great giving means giving up all internal and external things to the end and giving for a long time.
Freedom from faults means being free from faults such as unequal pursuit and so forth.
Freedom from defilements means permanently severing all stinginess that is to be eliminated.
As the Sutra of Inexhaustible Wisdom says in the section on the inexhaustibility of giving:
What is freedom from defilements?
Permanently severing what is to be eliminated along with its habitual tendencies.
In this way, the three phrases show the three kinds of supremacy of the perfections.
What are the three?
First, the most excellent essence and its accumulation, second, the most excellent means, and third, the most excellent fruit.
As for accumulation, it means giving for a long time.
Just as there are three kinds of giving pÄramitÄ, so it is also with wisdom pÄramitÄ.
As for morality and so forth being free from faults, it means being free from the increase of self and so forth, as appropriate, as extensively explained in the Aká¹£ayamatisÅ«tra.
Moreover, because it is associated with twelve kinds of most excellent, it is called pÄramitÄ.
What are called the twelve most excellent?
First, the most excellent vastness, because it does not seek any worldly happiness, and because it is supreme.
Second, the most excellent length of time, because it is accumulated over three great incalculable eons.
Third, the most excellent object, because it is for the benefit and happiness of all sentient beings.
Fourth, the most excellent inexhaustibility, because it is dedicated to great enlightenment and is ultimately inexhaustible.

The fifth is the supremacy of the uninterrupted, because one attains the superior understanding of the equality of self and others, causing sentient beings to quickly perfect the perfections such as giving.
The sixth is the supremacy of the absence of difficulty, because one causes the perfections to be quickly perfected by merely rejoicing in the giving, etc., practiced by others.
The seventh is the supremacy of great mastery, because one causes the perfections such as giving to be quickly perfected by attaining samÄdhis such as the treasury of space.
The eighth is the supremacy of inclusion, because they are included in nondiscriminating cognition.
The ninth is the supremacy of arousal, referring to the perfections such as giving practiced on the stage of resolve and practice in the state of superior patience.
The tenth is the supremacy of realization, referring to the perfections such as giving attained in the first stage.
The eleventh is the supremacy of outflow, referring to the perfections such as giving practiced in the remaining eight stages.

The twelfth is that of supremacy, which refers to the perfections of giving, etc., in the tenth stage and in the stage of the TathÄgata, because the bodhisattva perfects them in the tenth stage and the Buddha perfects them in the stage of the TathÄgata.

Moreover, they are called perfections because they are the most excellent of all that is to be done and because they are the most excellent of all that is to be reached, because they are the doing and the reaching of all Buddhas and bodhisattvas.
Moreover, they are called perfections because they reach the other shore of the knowable, because they abide in the nature of Buddhahood.

Moreover, they are called perfections because they save oneself and others from the most extreme calamities, because they enable oneself and others to transcend the great suffering of the ocean of birth and death.
The common terms have been explained. The uncommon ones will now be discussed.
Because it can abandon giving and future poverty and suffering, and because it can abandon acceptance and present heat and distress, it is called giving.
Because it can cause the sense organs to be eternally tranquil, because it can lead to the pure good destinies, and because it can serve as a basis for coolness, it is called morality.

Because they can respectively lead to and guard the sense-organs, because they are the cause for going to the pure good destinies, and because they can serve as the basis for the gradual sequence up to nirvana, beginning with non-remorse.

It is called patience because it is far removed from all the ashes of anger and heat, because it is far removed from the mind of not abandoning enmity, and because it manifests the constant peace and security of the one who harms.
The mind of enmity refers to the mind of retaliation.
Not abandoning means not discarding this mind.
The one who can destroy the mind of enmity is called the one who harms.
In order to manifest this fearlessness, it is said that it manifests the constant peace and security of the one who harms.

It is called vigor because it is associated with the function of destroying and nourishing.ğŸ”½That which is associated with the function of destroying refers to the first two right efforts, because they can destroy unwholesome dharmas.
That which is associated with the function of nourishing refers to the latter two right efforts, because they can nourish wholesome dharmas.
It can uphold, it can stop, it can calm, it can regulate, and it can also induce, therefore it is called meditative absorption.
Can uphold means fixing the mind on an object.
Can stop means stopping all distractions.
Can calm means making the mind tranquil.
Can regulate means subduing the afflictions.
Can induce means being able to induce mastery and function.

Because it is the wisdom produced by others, because it is the wisdom of inner realization, because it is the wisdom of discrimination, because it is the wisdom of attaining tranquility, and because it is the wisdom of superior qualities, it is called wisdom.
Wisdom produced by others refers to the wisdom born from the speech of others and the wisdom associated with proper attention.
Wisdom of inner realization refers to supramundane wisdom.
Wisdom of discrimination refers to the wisdom attained after the supramundane [wisdom].
Wisdom of attaining tranquility refers to the wisdom that eliminates afflictions in the path of cultivation.
Wisdom of superior qualities refers to the wisdom that can induce superior qualities.
